Advanced engine technologies and environmental restrictions require new-generation automotive catalysts to be low-temperature (LT) active and high-temperature (HT) stable simultaneously. Here, incorporation of Ag over high temperature (800 °C) treated Pt/CeO2 was applied to address the challenge. Strong Pt-O-Ce bonds in Pt/CeO2 helped improve thermal stability dramatically. Detailed reaction kinetics analysis indicated Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism for Ag/CeO2 catalysts and Mars-van Krevelen (Mvk) mechanism for both Pt/CeO2 and Ag/Pt/CeO2 catalyst. After calcined at 800 °C, CO adsorbed on ionic Pt site could be readily oxidized by neighbouring oxygen species at a temperature as low as 132 °C over Ag/Pt/CeO2, about 60 °C lower than Pt/CeO2 and Ag/CeO2. Raman spectroscopy and XPS results suggested that incorporation of Ag created more oxygen defects over Pt/CeO2 and oxygen species on Ag nanoparticles might be more active than bare Pt/CeO2 which would enhance the low-temperature activity for Ag/Pt/CeO2. It might be an effective and cost-efficient approach to develop new catalysts for vehicle emission oxidation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Each keyword to start on a new line Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The most harmful emissions take place during the cold-start period for internal combustion engine vehicles. Continuously improving low-temperature activity of automotive after-treatment catalyst remains a cutting-edge R&D area [1,2]. On the other hand, a vehicle emission catalyst needs to tolerate high temperature up to 1000 °C [3]. Thus, development of vehicle emission catalysts with excellent low-temperature (LT, <200 °C) activity as well as high-temperature (HT, >800 °C) stability is still a formidable challenge. The most widely used three-way catalysts (TWCs) are noble metals (Pt, Pd, Rh etc.) supported on oxides, normally a combination of Al2O3, CeO2, ZrO2 and CeZrO2 etc. [4]. In manufactory, the cost-inefficient high loading of platinum group metals (PGMs) is usually required to achieve sufficient LT activity to meet the emission standards [5]. Thus, the exploration for PGM reduction or even replacement is necessary for developing more economic TWC systems. Among all the other metals, Ag has been reported to exhibit similar low temperature activity in CO oxidation reactions. Fei et al. reported that the Ag0/Al2O3 treated at 600 °C demonstrated better CO oxidation performance than single-atom Ag/Al2O3 and the Ag/Al2O3 treated at 400 and 800 °C. DFT calculations showed that the larger metallic Ag particles were beneficial for O2 dissociation and stability, but a particle size too large drastically reduced the number of active sites, resulting in a sharp drop of activity [6]. However, further improvement of the LT activity and HT stability is still a great challenge for Ag based catalysts. Cerium dioxide (CeO2) is widely employed as the support or additive in a variety of oxidation reaction catalysts, due to its reversible Ce4+/Ce3+ redox shuttle, which provides excellent ability to store and release oxygen [7–10]. In order to improve the CO and hydrocarbon oxidation activity, CeO2 is adopted as an essential component in three-way catalysts (TWCs) and diesel oxidation catalysts. The oxygen storage capacity (OSC) could not only improve the CO oxidation activity, but also expands the air-to-fuel ratio “window” under which acceptable catalyst performance is achieved for all three reactants. However, ceria shows severe sintering at high temperatures. Addition of Zr can further improve the OSC and it has been reported that 40−60 % ceria content leads to the highest OSC, and thus enhance catalyst performance [11,12]. But the zirconia-ceria system suffers from the high temperature phase separation [13], which limits its applications at high temperatures [14–16]. Metal doping is another way to improve the OSC and LT activity. For example, over Cu-modified CeO2, Pt could be activated to one order of magnitude more active than atomically dispersed Pt catalyst over bare CeO2 [17]. Bing et al. found that on SiO2 support the Pt-Bi cluster formed by Bi doping could be activated by CO at low temperature (∼50 °C) leading to a high CO2 production rate of 487 μmol CO2 · gPt −1 · s−1 at 110 °C [18]. However, although doping is an efficient way to improve the activity, the HT stability is not always warranted. New method is needed to promote the structure sustainability while keeping the LT activity simultaneously. Recently, high-temperature steam pretreatment has been reported to be an efficient approach to raise the activity of Pt and Pd catalysts magnitudes higher in CO and CH4 oxidation [19,20]. And at the same time possess the ability to maintain the catalyst structures and activities after high temperature thermal treatment. However, the approach requires tedious catalyst preparation and pretreatment steps which are time consuming and expensive. On the other hand, it has been known that Pt could form oxidized Pt-O-Ce bonds in presence of oxygen [21], which could stabilize the Pt species in a dispersed state. But the influence of the Pt-O-Ce bonds on the ceria support stability has not been discussed in depth and fully understood. Herein, we demonstrate an alternative approach to incorporate LT active Ag on thermal stable Pt/CeO2 to Ag/Pt/CeO2 catalysts. The catalyst shows good LT activity (light-off <200 °C) as well as excellent HT thermal stability (up to 800 °C for 6 h). In this contribution, Pt atoms might not be the low-temperature catalytic active sites but the structure stabilizer for the catalyst. Pretreatment of Pt/CeO2 at 800 °C in air leads to strong Pt-O-Ce bonds which help stabilize the CeO2 support at harsh conditions [22], while provides sufficient surface area to load the second metal Ag. Ag was subsequently impregnated onto such Pt/CeO2 which then exhibited noticeably promoted LT CO oxidation activity. The usage of Pt is significantly lower than the traditional Pt based TWC catalysts, making this catalyst both effective and cost efficient for emission control applications. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (8 wt.%, Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., LTD), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Ag(NO3)2 and CH3CH2OH (Sinopharm Chemical ReagentCo., Ltd), deionized water. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of CeO2 polyhedra Ceria support was prepared by annealing. The Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was heated in air at 350 °C for 2 h to obtain CeO2 polyhedra [23]. 2.2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The Pt/Ce800 catalyst with 1 wt.% platinum was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method. An appropriate amount of 8 wt.% H2PtCl6 aqueous solution was added drop-wise to the CeO2 while kept grounding in a mortar and pestle, and then dried at 80 °C for 6 h. Sequentially, the samples were calcined at 800 °C for 6 h. The catalyst was designated as Pt/Ce800. The Ag/CeO2 catalysts, with 5 wt.% sliver, were prepared by (IWI) method as well. The CeO2 was impregnated with an aqueous solution of AgNO3 followed by drying at 80 °C for 6 h. Afterwards the sample were respectively calcined and thermally aged at 500, 600, 700, 800 °C for 6 h in flowing air. The catalysts were designated as Ag/Ce500, Ag/Ce600, Ag/Ce700, Ag/Ce800 in line with different calcination temperature. All the bimetallic Ag/Pt/CeO2 catalysts were prepared based on Pt/Ce800 with 5 wt.% sliver loading. The AgNO3 aqueous solution was added drop-wise to the Pt/Ce800 followed by drying at 80 °C for 6 h. Afterwards the sample was directly calcined and thermally aged at 500 and 800 °C for 6 h in flowing air. The resulting sample is designated as Ag/PtCe500, Ag/PtCe800. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts The crystal phase structure of catalysts was analysed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) instrument (Advance D8, Bruker). The Cu Kα monochromatized radiation (λ = 0.1541 nm) was selected. The available scanning range was 10-80° and its scanning speed was 2° min−1. The specific surface area of the samples was determined by N2 sorption at -196 °C using ASAP 2460 (Micromeritics). Before the analysis, all samples were outgassed at 300 °C under vacuum. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The Raman spectra were registered at ambient conditions using an DXR2 XI Raman microscope (ThermoFisher). Laser wavelength is 532 nm, grating is 900 lines/nm, diaphragm is 50 μm. The X - ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried with an EscalabXi+ (ThermoFisher). This system uses a focused monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source for excitation. The microstructural observations were performed with a probe corrected Talos F200X electron microscope (ThermoFisher). The observations were done in Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) mode using a High Angle Annular Dark Field Detector (HAADF). Before testing, the catalyst was finely ground and then ultrasonically dispersed in 5 mL ethanol for 10 min. After standing, 5 drops of the supernatant solution were added to the copper grid, followed by drying and testing. In situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) measurements were performed on an IR spectrometer NICOLET iS50 FT-IR (ThermoFisher), coupled with a Praying Mantis™ Diffuse Reflection accessory (Harrick) with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The catalyst was firstly activated at 573 K with 20 % O2/Ar at 300 °C for 1 h (40sccm), followed cooling down to 150 °C. Then the background spectrum was recorded. The adsorbed gas (2 % CO and 10 % O2 balanced with Ar) was then introduced into the reaction cell and the IR spectra were recorded. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The CO oxidation reaction was conducted in an atmospheric pressure fixed bed flow reactor system. 37.5 mg of catalyst, sieved to 40 to 60 mesh, was diluted with inert SiO2 powder (375 mg) to prevent temperature gradients. The catalyst was pretreated with 125sccm (standard cubic centimeter per minute) of 20 % O2/Ar at 300 °C for 1 h. After colling to room temperature, the feed gas consists 2 % CO and 10 % O2 balanced with Ar, passed through the reactor with a flow rate of 125sccm. The reaction temperature was ramped up from 25 °C to 300 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C /min. Outlet gas composition was measured by a gas chromatograph Agilent 7890B, using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization results To simulate real harsh working conditions of vehicle emission, all the catalysts were calcined up to 800 °C. Fig. 1 a shows that the surface area of Ag/Ce catalysts decrease dramatically with increasing calcination temperature (42.8 m2/g after 500 °C calcination to 3.6 m2/g after 800 °C calcination). The CO oxidation reaction was conducted at a high space velocity of 200,000 ml gcat –1 h–1 to simulate real working conditions. The temperature required for 50 % CO conversion (T50) over Ag/Ce catalysts increased from 168 °C (Ag/Ce500) to 437 °C (Ag/Ce800), probably due to Ag particle sintering and surface area loss caused by high temperature calcination in Fig. 1b and Fig. S1 (Ag HR-TEM). The average Ag particle sizes were calculated from the Ag (111) X-ray diffraction peaks by the Scherrer equation, Table. S1. The average Ag particle size increased from 27 nm to 41.7 nm when calcination temperature increased from 500 °C to 700 °C. However, for the Ag/Ce800 sample, the average Ag particle size was only 36.1 nm. High temperature 800 °C calcination might lead to redispersion of Ag over CeO2, similar with previous reports [24]. It was known that smaller Ag nanoparticle exhibited higher CO oxidation activity [25]. However, other parameters such as the CeO2 support surface defect density and catalyst surface area also had critical influence on the catalytic activity. As a result of all the factors, higher calcination temperature led to lower CO oxidation light-off activity for all the Ag/CeO2 samples. Considering the very low surface area of Ag/Ce800 sample (3.6 m2/g), the catalytic thermal stability of bare Ag/CeO2 samples is limited since high temperature calcination would ruin its LT activity. Thus, preservation of surface area in high temperature treatment might be crucial to preserve the LT activity of the catalysts. For Pt/CeO2 (Pt/Ce800), although calcined at 800 °C, it maintained a surface area of 27.1 m2/g in agreement with previous reports (Fig. 1a) [19]. It was known that calcination at high temperatures under oxygen-rich conditions leads to formation of strong Pt-O-Ce bonds which helped to stabilize the Pt/Ce800 catalyst under harsh conditions [22]. However, the T50 for Pt/Ce800 is only 408 °C, showing limited LT activity. Reduction in H2 or CO led to formation of Pt nanoparticles which could increase the LT activity for Pt/Ce800 dramatically, but the increase is temporary since air would eventually re-oxidize and re-disperse the Pt nanoparticles [24]. In summary, neither Ag/CeO2 or Pt/CeO2 alone calcined at 800 °C could meet the requirements for simultaneous HT stability and LT activity. To make best use of the advantages of Ag and Pt and bypass their disadvantages, Ag was subsequently incorporated over Pt/Ce800 (resulted in Ag/PtCe samples) and calcined at 800 °C. The preparation steps were mentioned earlier in the text with details in the SI. As predicted, the T50 of Ag/PtCe800 is 301 °C which is about 50 °C lower than that of both Ag/Ce800 and Pt/CeO2 (Fig. 1c). A higher surface area for Ag/PtCe800 compared to Ag/Ce800 might help retain smaller Ag nanoparticles and sequentially exhibited a much higher activity (Table. S1) [6]. Considering that the Ag/PtCe800 catalyst was calcined at 800 °C, it can be concluded that Ag/PtCe800 exhibits good LT activity and HT stability simultaneously. The result demonstrates that incorporating LT active metal such as Ag over Pt/Ce800 (stabilized by strong metal-support interaction, SMSI) should be an effective approach to develop a catalyst which is both LT active and HT stable for CO oxidation. Over all Pt containing samples, Pt remains highly dispersed at atomic level, since no Pt particles or Pt XRD peaks were observed (Fig. 1d). Raman spectroscopy was used to study the lattice oxygen defects and content of oxygen vacancies in Fig. 2 a. According to the values of full width half maximum of D band (FWHMD), Ag-containing catalysts possess higher content of oxygen vacancies (Table. S2). Raman peaks at ∼560 cm−1 and ∼672 cm−1 can be assigned to the Pt-O-Ce vibration and Pt-O vibration of Pt-O-Ce bond, respectively. The results support that Pt is anchored on the surface oxygen of ceria to form Pt-O-Ce bond [26]. XPS data indicated that the addition of Ag increases the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies that the OV/(OV+OL) (OV denotes O in the oxygen vacancies, OL denotes O in the lattice) values increase from 0.08 to 0.17 (Fig. 2b, Fig. S4 and Table. S3), consistent with the Raman results. It was discussed earlier that the Pt-O-Ce in Pt/Ce800 would limit LT activity but enhance HT stability dramatically [27]. Thus, the reaction kinetics is applied to further study the key factors for the LT catalytic performance including the state of Ag and surface oxygen vacancy. 3.2 Reaction kinetics for CO oxidation Reaction kinetics was investigated without internal and external mass transfer limitations which was confirmed by varying catalyst powder meshes and feed flow rates. The apparent activation energies for Pt/Ce800, Ag/Ce500 and Ag/PtCe800 were calculated to be 80.5, 48.2 and 42.9 kJ/mol, respectively (Fig. 3 a). The values indicate that the reaction mechanism for Pt/Ce800 may be different from the two Ag-containing catalysts. Reaction mechanism for low-temperature CO oxidation over atomically dispersed Pt has been studied extensively. The Mars-Van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism and Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism were proposed for different catalysts and conditions [28–31]. And it was usually considered to be Mvk mechanism over Pt1/CeO2 catalyst. If we assume surface reaction between absorbed species is the rate-limiting step, the elementary steps are as following (1) to (3): (1) CO + * ⇌ CO * (2) O 2 + # ⇌ O 2 # (3) CO * + O 2 # → krds Product Rate Determining Step (RDS) (*) represents active sites for CO adsorption. CO adsorbed over Pt sites is not catalytic active in the temperature range of this work and only CO adsorbed on Ag sites is considered. (#) represents Ag, CeO2 or interfacial sites for O2 adsorption. (4) Coverage : θ ( CO ) = K 1 P CO 1 + K 1 P CO (5) θ ( O 2 ) = K 2 P O 2 1 + K 2 P O 2 K1: adsorption equilibrium constant for CO. K2: adsorption equilibrium constant for O2. The rate equation can be written as: (6) r = k rds · θ ( CO ) · θ ( O 2 ) = k rds K 1 P CO K 2 P O 2 ( 1 + K 1 P C O ) * ( 1 + K 2 P O 2 ) (7) r = C 1 · P CO P O 2 ( 1 + K 1 P CO ) · ( 1 + K 2 P O 2 ) Since the catalytic tests were conducted at oxygen rich environment, PCO is relatively low and PO2 is more than one order of magnitude larger. We could assume that K2PO2 >>1, then Eq. (6) can be simplified as (8) r = C 3 · P CO ( 1 + K 1 P CO ) 0th order for O2. If we further assume that K1PCO ≪1, then Eq. (8) is further simplified as: (9) r = C 2 · P CO 1st order for CO. So based on the apparent reaction orders, we could deduce the adsorption behavior of CO and O2 on the catalyst surface. The apparent reaction orders of O2 are -0.14, -0.08 and 0.07 for Pt/Ce800, Ag/Ce500 and Ag/PtCe800 respectively (Fig. 3b). The slight negative O2 order indicates relatively strong adsorption of O2 on surface oxygen vacancies. However, to simplify the discussion, it should be reasonable to approximately assume the O2 order for all three catalysts as 0. From Eq. (8) above, the nearly zero order for O2 indicates K2PO2 >>1 which is in accordance with the relatively strong O2 adsorption over the catalysts or high coverage of O2 on the surface [32]. When keeping partial pressure of O2 constant in the tests, all O2 terms would be constants. Then the rate equation is also simplified to Eq. (8). Take reciprocal of both sides of Eq. (8): (10) 1 r = 1 C 3 · 1 P CO + K 1 C 3 When making a linear plot for 1/r and 1/PCO, the slope is 1/C3 and the intercept is K1/C3. The CO adsorption equilibrium constant K1 is then equal to Intercept/Slope in Eq. (10). The derivation process assuming dissociative adsorption of O2 was included in Scheme S1. Except that the K and C3 were changed to root terms, similar results were obtained. According to Eq. (10), the CO adsorption equilibrium constants were calculated to be 0.00005 and 0.0002 for Pt/Ce800 and Ag/PtCe800 respectively, while the apparent reaction orders of CO are 1.08 and 0.68 correspondingly (Figs. 3c and 3 d). Again, in Pt/Ce800, the Pt remained mainly at highly dispersed state as Pt-O-Ce bonds so the CO reaction order is close to 1 which is different from negative CO order obtained over Pt clusters or nanoparticle catalysts [33]. Corresponding to the close to 1 apparent reaction order of CO over Pt/Ce800, the CO adsorption equilibrium constant being close to 0 indicates negligible CO adsorption over Pt/Ce800 at such reaction temperature (306 °C). It is in agreement with recent study that CO adsorbed over atomically-dispersed Pt/Ce800 would desorb below 200 °C [17]. Here, the reaction should follow MvK mechanism. The rate-limiting step involves gaseous CO reacting with oxygen species on the catalyst surface [34]. Once the temperature was reduced to 150 °C, CO adsorbed over ionic Pt sites could be detected clearly by CO-DRIFTS (Fig. S2a). Furthermore, the CO peaks exhibited only a slight drop after stopping CO in the gas flow. It is therefore verified that CO adsorbed over ionic Pt sites is inactive at such low temperature [19]. On the contrary, CO adsorbed over Ag/Ce500 fully dropped within 4 min after stopping CO in the gas flow (Fig. S2b). The results agree well with the more than one order of magnitude higher LT activity for Ag/Ce500 than Pt/Ce800. The CO adsorption constant is 0.0002 for Ag/PtCe500 and a much higher value 0.00005 for Pt/Ce800 (Fig. 3d). The CO coverage over Ag/PtCe800 surface should be higher than Pt/Ce800, due to the possible interaction of Pt with Ag. CO-DRIFTS for Ag/PtCe800 was investigated at 150 °C (Fig. 4 ). At such temperature, Ag/Ce500 shows decent CO oxidation activity in light-off tests while Pt/Ce800 does not. The major IR bands are at 2170, 2121, 2098, 2088 and 2039 cm−1, and the corresponding CO adsorption sites were labelled in the figure [24,35,36]. Both 2170 and 2121 cm−1 bonds were attributed to gas phase CO. The band at lower wavenumbers (2088 and 2039 cm−1) are assigned to CO linearly adsorbed on isolated Pt2+ in a near-perfect square-planar Pt1O4 configuration, and the band at higher wavenumber of 2098 cm−1 is attributed to CO adsorbed on isolated Pt2+ with an asymmetric Pt1O4 geometry. Slightly different bond wavenumber (2098 vs. 2087 cm−1) might result from the existence of two different local environments of isolated Pt [36]. It is highly possible that the addition of Ag has altered the interaction of the Pt-O-Ce bond near Ag that leads to different types of Pt single atom. Under reaction conditions, CO on Pt sites were observed. However, after stopping CO in the flow, the bond for CO gas phase fully dropped in less than 4 min while CO on Pt in a much slower pace. According to Raman and XPS results, the introduction of Ag nanoparticles can increase the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, thus facilitating the activation of adsorbed O2. And CO adsorbed over Pt sites react with activated O2 more readily. Meanwhile, previous studies suggested that electron transfer takes place between Ag and the O2 molecule, weakening the OO bond and forming the O2− species, thereby enhancing oxygen activation [37,38]. In conclusion, the addition of Ag improved the reactivity of oxygen species on the catalyst surface. Thus, the catalytic activity of Ag/PtCe800 catalyst was noticeably increased comparing to either Ag/Ce800 or Pt/Ce800. CO-DRIFTS for Pt/Ce800 further verifies the above conclusion (Fig. S2a). Reaction mechanism for low-temperature CO oxidation over atomically dispersed Pt has been studied in literature [28]. In this work, no significant CO adsorption bonds at Ag sites were observed on Ag/CeO2 catalysts in Figs. S2a and S2c. So, it might be that gas phase CO reacted with the oxygen adsorbed on the Ag sites, the CeO2 surface or interfacial area [32,39]. Therefore, the ER mechanism should be applicable to Ag/CeO2 sample. For Ag/PtCe800 and Pt/Ce800 samples, CO adsorbed on ionic Pt sites (Fig. 4 and Figs. S2a) reacted with neighbouring oxygen species, thus followed MvK mechanism [30,31]. In Pt/Ce800 sample, thermal aging at 800 °C resulted in strong Pt-O-Ce bond formation which over-stabilized the surface lattice oxygen and led to a lack of reactivity to low temperature CO oxidation [27]. Meanwhile, both CO and O2 can be adsorbed at the Pt sites, so there is competition for adsorption. This also leads to a higher energy barrier for the CO oxidation reaction [40]. It is highly possible that the oxygen species adsorbed over Ag nanoparticles in Ag/PtCe800 sample were more active than that adsorbed on CeO2 surface in Pt/Ce800 sample, leading to a much higher low-temperature activity for Ag/PtCe800 than Pt/Ce800. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, high temperature aging led to surface area loss and Ag particle sintering for Ag/CeO2 catalyst thus ruined its low-temperature CO oxidation activity. However, strong Pt-O-Ce bonds in both the parent Pt/CeO2 and Ag/Pt/CeO2 dramatically increase the catalysts’ thermal stability under harsh aging temperature. Once the Ag nanoparticles was stabilized on Pt/CeO2, the LT CO oxidation activity was dramatically enhanced. Over Ag/CeO2 catalysts, gas phase CO reacted with active oxygen species on the catalyst surface following ER mechanism. Over both Pt/CeO2 and Ag/Pt/CeO2 catalysts, CO adsorbed on ionic Pt sites. So, the activity of adsorbed O2 determined the CO oxidation activity. Addition of Ag created more oxygen defects over Pt/CeO2, and oxygen species over Ag nanoparticles were more active. As a result, the low-temperature CO oxidation activity for Ag/Pt/CeO2 catalyst is more than one order of magnitude higher than that of Pt/CeO2. In catalyst development, active catalytic sites are usually not stable under harsh conditions while stable catalytic sites are usually not very active. The Ag/PtCe800 sample prepared in this contribution showed negligible catalytic activity loss even after calcined at 800 °C and started to be active at about 200 °C in the CO oxidation light-off test. The results might provide a rational catalyst development strategy to enhance both low-temperature catalytic activity and high-temperature stability simultaneously. coredata.dc:description: Advanced engine technologies and environmental restrictions require new-generation automotive catalysts to be low-temperature (LT) active and high-temperature (HT) stable simultaneously. Here, incorporation of Ag over high temperature (800 °C) treated Pt/CeO2 was applied to address the challenge. Strong Pt-O-Ce bonds in Pt/CeO2 helped improve thermal stability dramatically. Detailed reaction kinetics analysis indicated Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism for Ag/CeO2 catalysts and Mars-van Krevelen (Mvk) mechanism for both Pt/CeO2 and Ag/Pt/CeO2 catalyst. After calcined at 800 °C, CO adsorbed on ionic Pt site could be readily oxidized by neighbouring oxygen species at a temperature as low as 132 °C over Ag/Pt/CeO2, about 60 °C lower than Pt/CeO2 and Ag/CeO2. Raman spectroscopy and XPS results suggested that incorporation of Ag created more oxygen defects over Pt/CeO2 and oxygen species on Ag nanoparticles might be more active than bare Pt/CeO2 which would enhance the low-temperature activity for Ag/Pt/CeO2. It might be an effective and cost-efficient approach to develop new catalysts for vehicle emission oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Incorporation of Ag on stable Pt/CeO2 for low-temperature active and high-temperature stable CO oxidation catalyst
